abstracts.cdata!:
This is an environmental assessment of
            the Yangzhou Thermal Power project, which constructs a
            coal-fired thermal power plant, erects transmission lines,
            and reinforces the existing power transmission network.
            Environmental risks involving the power plant are: TPS, SO2
            and fluorides in the discharged flue gas; poisonous and
            harmful substances in the industrial effluents and living
            sewage discharges; noise pollution; the impact of ash and
            slag storage on land utilization and the atmosphere as well
            as the permeation of ash water into underground water; and
            electromagnetic radiation produced by the power lines. When
            constructing and operating the transmission line from
            Yangcheng to Jiangsu, more negative impacts are expected.
            These measures mitigate them: To reduce noise, adopt
            soundproofing measures, avoid working at night, and use a
            protective enclosure (afforesting switchyards). This
            protective barrier and the sprinkling of water will reduce
            dust. Collect water used in the switchyard and substation,
            and let it settle before discharging and reusing it. Treat
            sewage before discharging it. Replant trees to replenish
            forests. Replace the vegetal cover. Return land to farm use
            and pay compensation for agricultural land loss. Set up
            protected sites when cultural relics are found. Educate
            workers and nearby residents about power line safety. Pay
            compensation for occupying land and resettle people with
            improved public facilities and/or retrain them.
